Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant funds the research activities of Professor Jeffrey Harvey at the University of Chicago.

As part of this project, Professor Harvey plans to pursue several directions at the forefront of string theory. Specifically, he will investigate new connections between the mathematics of automorphic forms, the counting and structure of black hole states in supersymmetric string theories, the properties of supersymmetric states, and the representation theory of sporadic groups.

This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professor Harvey plans to integrate his research into undergraduate and graduate courses. He also intends to mentor graduate students and postdocs. His public outreach activities typically include occasional appearances on local radio and TV programs, public lectures at local theatres and schools, and the opportunity for postdocs to present the Compton Lecture Series, a series of Saturday morning lectures on physics to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to understand and further develop connections between some very special symmetry groups in mathematics and other mathematical objects called mock modular forms which appear in various computations in string theory. A very nice description of some of this work, aimed at the public, can be found in the article "Mathematicians chase moonshine's shadow" by Erica Klarreich" in the online magazine Quanta. The project led to the discovery of new examples of this ``moonshine" connection and further ties to geometry and string theory.  The most significant result was the discovery of Umbral Moonshine, which is described in the article mentioned above. This discovery has been of great interest to parts of the mathematical community, and research is ongoing to try and understand its implications for string theory, geometry and number theory. 

 

The project also led to the training of a postdoctoral associate, a graduate student, and an undergraduate at the University of Chicago. Further research in this area is ongoing and will train additional undergraduate and graduate students in aspects of mathematical physics. Results of the research were published in refereed journals, posted on the ArXiv, and presented at a number of schools and conferences. Many of these presentations are available in video format and can be accessed by the general public.
